Award.AwardTitle: GOALI/Collaborative Research: Antenna-Coupled ALD-Enabled Metal-Insulator-Insulator-Metal Diodes for High Responsivity and High Resolution THz/Infrared Focal Plane Arrays

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
GOALI/Collaborative Research: Antenna-Coupled ALD-Enabled Metal-Insulator-Insulator-Metal Diodes for High Responsivity and High Resolution THz/Infrared Focal Plane Arrays

The objective of this research is to develop a new class of room temperature metal-insulator-insulator-metal tunnel diode detectors and monolithically integrate them within novel miniature antenna focal plane array configurations for high resolution and high responsivity THz/infrared imaging as well as energy harvesting. The approach is to enhance nonlinearity of the diodes up to 30THz by using dual tunnel junctions and employ a system level design by addressing issues of antenna-diode impedance mismatches, compact antenna size, inter-element electromagnetic couplings, and bandwidth.

Intellectual Merits:
The program is focused on challenges associated with system-level integration of antenna coupled metal-insulator-insulator-metal diodes for high performance THz/infrared imaging. Metal-insulator-insulator-metal diodes offering sensitive detection of radiation up to 30THz will advance the synthesis of ultrathin dielectric materials and nanofabrication. The critical goals of high resolution and high responsivity will be achieved through novel approaches in antenna miniaturization, non-uniform array layouts, and compact impedance matching networks. Ultra-wideband imaging and energy harvesting will be accomplished with novel broadband arrays and computational electromagnetics modeling.

Broader Impacts:
The outcomes will impact a broad range of applications including environmental, biomedical, material science, homeland security, and renewable energy. The effort is well aligned with synergistic research in the area of medical THz imaging and infrared renewable energy at both universities. The industry partnership will allow to broadly disseminate research results beyond the academic community. The project will provide a system level design opportunity to graduate students, impact the curriculum at both universities, and leverage ongoing programs to attract underrepresented students to engineering.

ProgramReference.Text: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS

POR.DRECONTENT:
Under this project, we demonstrated, for the first time, a large-format THz focal plane array (FPA) camera for real-time, spectroscopic imaging and THz computed tomography applications, covering a broad frequency range between 500GHz and 1 THz.

Fast THz imaging and computed tomography enabled by the large-format FPA-based camera developed under this effort will enable new applications in many coveted areas of THz sensing and spectroscopy. Among science, industry, and societal impact, the following are the prominent applications: Security screening applications, new hyper-spectral biomedical imaging techniques, pharmaceutical and food security, and through-packaging/non-destructive evaluation/identification applications.

Unlike the state-of-the-art single-pixel THz sensors, our new many-pixel FPA can capture large-area images of the scene under test (much like an optical or infrared video camera). As such, our camera also enables much needed imaging of electrodynamic phenomena in this band and provides a direct visualization of important RF quantities such as antenna patterns, diffraction ripples, beam-forming etc. In addition, real-time performance of the portable THz camera is also unique and can be used as an educational tool in the classroom for demonstrating the physical nature of electromagnetic radiation.  

The OSU PI has published 3 journal papers and 11 conference presentations. OSU portion of this grant was also instrumental in establishing a state of the art THz laboratory at the Ohio State University funded by the State of Ohio Third Frontier Grant. The OSU HELIOS (Hyperspectral Engine Lab for Integrated Optical Systems) is now a fully-functional cost center and includes major THz spectroscopy instrumentation. It is open to external entities, such as small businesses and other academic institutions to utilize the quipment for academic as well as commercial interests. The PhD student supported by this grant not only helped devloped this unique laboratory, but also gave several OSU PhD students, including the supported student, to get trained for the operation of the state of the art THz measurement systems.

In addition, this grant helped the OSU PI attract one hispanic veteran student and one female student into the doctorate program at the Electrical and Computer Engineering Department at the Ohio State University. 

The OSU PI also incorporated parts of this effort into the mixed-level (undergraduate and graduate) "Photonics" class. The PI taught the class for the first time and prepared the associated teaching material.

The convergence of new solid-state devices, new antenna designs, and optimized quasi-optical coupling for real-time THz imaging is perhaps the most important aspect of this effort. As such, this project requires in-dept understanding in electromagnetic theory, solid state engineering and optics/photonics. This unique synergy is an excellent venue for demonstrating the interplay between these "apparently-disjoint" areas of electrical engineering and provides a great opportunity to facilitate learning and training in graduate-level engineering classes.

As part of educational impact of the project, we note that real-time large-format images of THz waves provide never-before-seen pictures of wave electrodynamics that are much needed for electromagnetics education. As such, this new capability allows for studnets to withness the underlying physics of many electromagnetic phenomena, such as wave propagation, diffraction, focusing, and spectroscopy,allowing for an in-depth understangding of abstract and mathematical formulations.

We are also proud that the THz camera developed under this effort is now available as a commercial product through our collaborator company, Traycer Diagnostics Inc.
